titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. My wife continues extremely ill, and growing worse through the day— Dr: Welsh was here in the morning, and again late this Evening; but without being able to obtain for her, any permanent relief— My own health continues bad. The symptoms of the cold growing heavier, and the cough more oppressive— A mixture of rasped spermaceti and loaf-sugar however relieves the soreness upon my lungs— My father and mother came through Boston this afternoon; attended the funeral of Mrs: Dana at Cambridge, and returned here to lodge this Night— Mr: Shaw was also here this Evening.

2. Mrs: Adams remained excessively ill the whole Night, and this Morning untill the Doctor gave her laudanum, which he had avoided as long as possible, but which we have found on such occasions the only thing that could procure relief for her— After taking this she was much easier, and twice in the course of the day slept for some time— Mr: James Lovell was here this morning, and spent a couple of hours with my father— At Noon my father and Mother returned to Quincy, and in the afternoon my Sister Smith came in with her son John, who went back, at Night— I renewed my note to I. P. Davis at the Branch Bank, and left the Note with Mr: Davis’s endorsement at the Bank, for discount to-morrow— My old Note is not yet taken up, and will not be payable untill the 6th:— I have been unable to write this day, my breast and lungs being still so severely affected— I have employed however all my spare time in reading, for the composition of my lectures.

3. My wife continues to be growing better, though very slowly— My own indisposition continues though much less severe than it has been— I was able this day to write a very little, but not upon my lecture— Excepting however a half an hour’s walk after dinner I confined myself the whole day to the house; and I read upon the subject of rythm and of numbers the abbé Batteux and whatever else I could find.

4. Mrs: Adams apparently still continues to be mending in health, but the child is this day somewhat indisposed— My own health seems also to be returning, and I have apparently nothing of the influenza left, but a slight cough, and great weakness— Discovered the difficulty of getting George to School— Was at my Office about an hour this morning; commenced again writing upon my Lecture, and began the first sketch of Lecture 28.

5. Mrs: Adams is again very unwell—the child has the thrush severely, and George this morning was taken with a fever, of considerable violence— I have only a remnant of my cough— My concern for my sick family, and the necessary attention to them very much interfered with all my voluntary occupations— After the operation of two
powerful medicines George was apparently better— Mrs: Adams seemed also recovering again in the Evening: John Smith came into town on horseback, and returned at Night— My Sister spent the Evening, at Mr: S. A. Otis’s—where I called for her, and came home with her— I read this day for the first time the Play of Pericles Prince of Tyre, contained in one of my Edition’s of Shakespear.

6. Mr: John Gardner called on me this morning with his two eldest children, Sally and John— My Sister Smith returned to Quincy this morning with her son John, who came in for her. I heard Mr: Emerson this forenoon, and a Mr: Thayer for him in the afternoon. Took George with me the whole day— The children are both not perfectly well— Mrs: Adams continues slowly mending— I read Tillotson’s Sermons 131. 132. 133. 134. to redeem the omission occasioned by my absence last week at Quincy.— Walk in the Mall with Dr: Welsh this Evening.

7. I pass’d the day principally at my Office, where I find more leisure and retirement for reading or writing than at home— I wrote accordingly more of my lecture than usual— Spent the Evening at Mr: Parkman’s; with the Trustees of the Humane Society— Mrs: Adams is still unable to leave her bed; and George continues so unwell that we were obliged to detain him at home from School.
8. Attended both parts of the day at my Office, but wrote not so much as yesterday— Called on Mr: Hall, at his Office, and at the Insurance Office— Mrs: Adams and the children continue recovering.
9. Spent the day again principally at my Office, and wrote moderately— Finished the first sketch of my Lecture 28. My brother and his wife were in town— Evening with the Club at Dr: Kirkland’s.

10. I took George with me to dine and pass the afternoon at Mr: John Gardner’s, with his eldest Son— Pass’d the day again at my Office, and began the outline of my Lecture 29.— Walk’d in the Evening with Mr: Gardner; but the more I read or write, the less I have to say.

11. After passing the day once more, It found it at my Office, I found it difficult to write as much as my usual quantity— Walk’d with Mr: J. Phillips in the Mall at the beginning of the Evening— Mr: S. Dexter called and spent a couple of hours with me afterwards.— I now read at my leisure, Burke’s works— I have read the Vindication of Natural Society, and am now upon the Sublime and Beautiful— At the Athenaeum I found this afternoon a treatise of Mr: Knight, where all the principles of this theory are contested.

12. I brought Mr: Gardner’s son John home with me to dine and spend the afternoon with George, which he did— I called this morning on Mr: Emerson this morning to request him to baptize my new born child to-morrow— He mentioned to me the arrival of Mr: Tayloe— I pass’d the day at my Office and wrote rather more than usual; though of matter, which will not be very serviceable— Evening walk in the Mall— On coming home I found my Sister’s son William at our house, just arrived from the State of New-York. He was very anxious to go out this Evening to Quincy; and went on horseback. Mrs: Adams rode out, for the second time since her confinement.

13. My child, born the 18th: of last month, was this afternoon baptized by Mr: Emerson, and received the name, of Charles-Francis—the first of which I gave him in remembrance of my deceased brother, and the second, as a token of honour to my old friend and patron judge Dana— Mrs: Adams was not well enough to attend at Church, but went to the door, and waited in the Carriage untill the ceremony was performed.— William and John Smith came in from Quincy, this morning, and returned in the afternoon— Mr: Buckminster arrived last Evening from England— I saw this day Mr: James White, who came in the ship with him— I read Tillotson’s Sermons 135 and 136.— Mr: Cary preached at Mr: Emerson’s this morning, and gave us a very good Sermon— His still is quite superior to the common rate of our preachers, and has considerable pretensions to elegance— Walk this Evening in the Mall.

14. Rain, a great part of this day and very cold— I did not attend at my Office, but called at Mr: Shaw’s, and at the Athenaeum— Wrote at home upon my lecture— Finished reading Burke on the sublime and beautiful.

15. Finished the first sketch of my Lecture 29. but wrote less than my usual portion— This afternoon Mr: Everett having returned from his excursion, called at my house, and purposes from this time to attend at my Office. I sought in the town for Dr: Waterhouse, but without meeting him.

16. I was employed most of the forenoon in seeking an opportunity for sending to Alexandria— Mr: Everett attended at the Office— Began my Lecture 25.— Club this Evening at Mr: W. Smith’s— Attendance thin.

17. I was employed part of this day, in negotiating bills on the house of W. and J. Willink, at Amsterdam, for the balance due from them on my father’s account— I agreed finally upon the terms with W. Cleland and this afternoon drew the bills. Every moment engaged upon such business, takes me from other important occupations— I wrote therefore less than my common rule requires; but began the first draught of Lecture 30.— Wrote also a little on the fair copy of Lecture 25— I received also an application from a Mr: Phillips of Lynn, who came with Mr: James Gardner, and wished to obtain a discharge from the Marine Corps for his Son— I recommended an application to the Secretary of the Navy; and promised to write to him on the subject.

18. Wrote to the Secretary of the Navy, and enclosed to him the certificate of minority, and Quakerism of young Phillips— Finished also the negotiation for the bills on Messrs: W. and J. Willink—and wrote them letters of advice— Called this Evening at Shaw’s Office— On returning home, I found Mr: DeGrand at my house, and played with him at Chess— I finished reading Burke’s Observations on a late State of the Nation, one of his earliest political works; upon topics of little permanent interest, and professedly written in answer to a pamphlet now totally forgotten— The most valuable part in it now, is that which related to America— Containing the same Principles which he afterwards further displayed in his parliamentary Speeches; principles under which these United States would still at this day have been an appendage of Great-Britain— Mr: Gallison, attended this morning at the Office; but was desirous of spending the Winter, during my absence, at home— To which I consented.

19. I scarcely know why the fact is so, but without doing any thing else this day, I wrote very little on my Lecture. Attended however at my Office both morning and afternoon— Walk’d in the Mall with J. Gardner, in the Evening. Began the perusal of Burke’s Thoughts on the present Discontents—1770.

20. Mr: Foster, my neighbour brought me home this morning a letter, belonging to Mrs: Adams, which George had taken from her draw, and carried over to make a present of it to Miss Virginia— George is making love to Miss Virginia, and told her that when he knew how to write he would write to her himself; but in the mean time he would give her a letter written by somebody else. This letter which was from Eliza Johnson, he secretly took, and carried over to her— My Foster, finding it in the hands of some person in his family, brought it to me himself— George’s expedient was much like that of Pipes, in Peregrine Pickle— His associations of ideas are numerous, and often eccentric— They appear to be always just as far as his knowledge extends— His absurdities arise from Conclusions drawn under ignorance, and therefore with neglect of material parts of the premises— I heard Mr: Buckminster both parts of this day.— His text was from Proverbs XVI.9. A man’s heart deviseth his way: but the Lord directeth his steps. The Sermon, which extended through both Services, was a Comment upon the Vanity of human wishes, and the superior beneficence of Providence— The train of thought was precisely that of Juvenal and Johnson— The Sentiments were new dress’d, in very handsome attire— His composition is highly animated, and ornamented; his Imagination splendid and lively— His style sufficiently polished, and his delivery duly accented, emphatic and paused. That his pronunciation is elaborate appeared from a self-correction which he made in reading the Psalm. The lines were—

lg.l: Fear him, ye Saints, and you shall then

div.p:
He read the first line half through, accenting only the first syllable Fear—he then stopp’d in the middle of the verse, and repeated from the beginning Fear him ye Saints &c—and yet he did not in the second line accent either else or to; both of which I think should be accented, to complete the antithesis— His Doctrine, did not altogether correspond with my opinions— To inculcate that nothing, or next to nothing of our happiness in this world depends upon ourselves, is not, I believe, either moral or religious truth— Nor is it at all a cheering theory.— His prayers were quite original in thought and expression— That of the afternoon appeared to have been written— He baptiz’d three children—two of them Mr: H. G. Otis’s youngest boys William Foster and Alleyne. His performance of this duty was also peculiar to himself; and his prayer connected it well with his Sermon. My George
George dined, and pass’d the afternoon, after Church, at Mr: Gardner’s, with his children— Mrs: Adams rode out. I walk’d with Mr: Gardner in the Evening.

21. My Mother and Sister Smith came into Town this morning, and brought our son John with them. I saw them only for a few minutes, and then was in some agitation upon account of George, who had stroll’d all day about the town, and at 5 in the afternoon came in so unwell as to alarm his mother very much— I wrote however to my father and brother. Called this morning at Mrs: Carter’s to see Mr: Tayloe, but he was not at his lodgings— In the Evening I took a solitary walk in the Mall.— I met Dr: Hayward this morning, who spoke to me concerning some legal controversy of the long wharf; and who told me that he should place his son George with me; he has however yet two years to remain at College.

22. Spent the day principally at my Office, and finished my Lecture 25. Mr: Boies called upon me this morning; but I was not prepared with my papers.— With my usual time allotted for exercise, I did less than my customary task— Last Evening I finished Burke’s thoughts on the Cause of the present Discontents 1770—which he imputes entirely to the double Cabinet, or Back-stairs influence— Dr: Waterhouse yesterday inoculated with the vaccine matter, my infant boy, Charles.

23. I began this day upon my Lecture 26—but was so much engaged with other business that I wrote but little. Principally collecting Books to be sent for the College Library.— Part of the afternoon I pass’d at the Athenaeum. Club this Evening at Dr: Warren’s— Dr: Spooner and Mr: Tyng being out of town— It was not very fully attended— Mr: Buckminster was there.— Finished reading Burke’s first volume.

24. Dr: Waterhouse was in town, and call’d to see my child who he thinks has taken the vaccine inoculation— I attended but a very short time at my Office— On coming home this Evening I found Mrs: Adams was gone to pass the afternoon at Mrs: Welsh’s— I went there to meet her and just as I got there found her getting into the Carriage to come home. I came with her— Mr: Boies called on me this afternoon at my Office, and I took with him the admeasurement of my land behind the house; for the boundaries— He is to put up a fence there— Wrote very little.

25. Employed the greater part of this day in writing, on the Sketch of my 30th: and the copy of my 26th: lecture; and I spent my time accordingly, almost entirely at home, or at my Office— Took my children with me there this afternoon— Walk’d this Evening in the Mall.

26. I did not attend this day at my Office, being employed all the morning at home— In the afternoon, my Sister’s son William came in from Quincy, and I went out there with him— Took George with me, but left John in town— I found my father and mother both very unwell.

27. Heard the young Mr: Norton of Hingham, whom I have heard twice before this Summer, and whose pronunciation is so unpleasant.— In the Evening I went with George to Mr: Cranch’s, and engaged Mrs: Cranch to take my son John at board this Winter.— My Mother was confined almost the whole of this day to her chamber.

28. My Mother had an indifferent Night, and this morning so ill as to give me great concern— I returned this morning to Boston in the Stage with George, and employed the day in writing, partly at home, and partly at my Office. I was not very well myself, and more affected in Spirits than in health— Walk’d alone this Evening, and retired very early to bed.

29. My Sister’s son William came into town this afternoon, and returned with Caroline to Quincy this Evening.— My Mother is much better. Dr: Waterhouse called here twice in the course of the day to see our child, whose vaccine inoculation has succeeded, and whose arms are at the height of their inflammation— Dr: Welsh also called upon us this Evening. I looked at the Comet which has been visible for several days; and examined it through a glass at Mr: Brimmer’s— It is the first Comet I ever saw.— Called with Mrs: Adams at Mrs: Storer’s; but she was not at home— Also at Mr: Smith’s.

30. My Sister’s son John, came in from Quincy with Mrs: T. B. Adams— He dined with us, and returned at Night, to Quincy. Pass’d as much of the day, as I could dispose of, at my Office, and wrote as much as I could there— The Club, this Evening was at my house— About half the members attended— Mr: Silliman of New-Haven, and Coll: Gibbs of Newport, came with judge Davis.

Day— I rise about 7. in the morning— Read and hear George read untill 9. Breakfast.— Write at home, or at my Office untill 1.— Visit the Insurance-Office and read Newspapers untill 2.— Home to dinner— After which write again at home or at my Office untill dark— Evening untill 9. with my wife, or hearing George read— Sup— Read about an hour after supper— Bed between 10 and 11.
